"Minari" is a beautiful film, and its cinematography is indeed stunning. The film's cinematographer, Lachlan Milne, is an Australian-born cinematographer who has worked on several films and television shows. His work on "Minari" has received widespread critical acclaim, and he's been nominated for several awards, including the Academy Award for Best Cinematography.

Milne's cinematography in "Minari" is notable for its warm and intimate portrayal of the Korean-American experience. He used a combination of 35mm film and digital cameras to capture the film's nostalgic and dreamlike quality. The film's color palette is also noteworthy, with a focus on earthy tones and muted colors that evoke a sense of nostalgia and simplicity.

If you're interested in learning more about cinematography, I'd recommend checking out some online resources, such as the American Society of Cinematographers (ASC) website, which features interviews and articles about cinematographers and their work. You could also check out some cinematography-focused podcasts, such as "The Cinematography Podcast" or "The Film Look".

Additionally, you might want to explore the work of other cinematographers who have worked on films that you've enjoyed. For example, you could look up the work of Roger Deakins, who has worked on films like "No Country for Old Men", "Skyfall", and "Blade Runner 2049". Or, you could check out the work of Rachel Morrison, who was the first woman to be nominated for an Academy Award for Best Cinematography for her work on "Mudbound".
